Topic.Title: Why Yahoo Is Worth $34

Message.Msg: I like your thinking. I would think Yahoo will want to keep purchasing as many shares as they can right now at this low price. They could probably spend $9 billion to buy back 300 million shares and take the share count to 800 million shares outstanding. If that's the case, at $60 per share, market cap would be $48 billion, less than 100% gain from this level. With alibaba, YJ and any kind of growth of revenue, I think we will see this price per share sometime within the next 18 months.

Message.Title: A Secretive Vulture Investor Is Focusing on Yahoo
Message.Msg: Geier812's cover is blown... Alden Global Capital, with a 13F equity portfolio of $567 million, is run by Randall Smith, who is politely called a recluse among notoriously guarded hedge fund managers. Little is known about Smith – no one even knows his actual age or where he got his start – but he has been called the “pioneer of vulture investing.” While this may not be a term of endearment, Smith has endured by being diversified among the major sectors such as industrial goods, technology, financial stocks and consumer goods. With 5.3 million shares, Yahoo! occupies the number one position. The stock hit a new 52-week high on Apr. 15, but has drifted lower following disappointing Q1 earnings. First quarter earnings aside, there are still plenty of reasons why Yahoo! will remain one of the stronger stocks in the tech sector. Recent partnerships with Dropbox, Alibaba (which is expected to go public at $80 billion) and Flickr are providing Yahoo! with diversity that goes well beyond its core business of search engines and email. Not to mention that the company has great metrics, with a price/book ratio of 1.8 versus an industry average of 4.0 and a trailing P/E ratio of 7.2 versus 25 for Google.
